title: 111_hr2241
content: The Act titled "Equitable Compensation for American Victims of Torture Act of 2009" aims to provide justice for victims of torture and terrorism. During the Gulf War in 1991, Americans serving in the US Armed Forces were captured, tortured, and subjected to horrendous acts by Saddam Hussein's regime. CBS News reporter Bob Simon and cameraman Roberto Alvarez were also kidnapped and tortured. Many US citizens were detained and beaten following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August 1990. During the 1991 Gulf War, CBS News reporter Bob Simon and cameraman Roberto Alvarez were kidnapped and tortured by Iraq, along with American POWs. The Department of State classified Iraq as a state sponsor of terrorism at that time. During the Gulf War, Iraq tortured American POWs and civilians to prevent US military intervention in Kuwait. The victims suffered long-term physical and emotional damage. Upon their return, they were welcomed as heroes by Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney. During the Gulf War, American POWs were tortured by Iraq. Upon their return, they were welcomed as heroes by Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney. Congress passed resolutions condemning Iraq's treatment of POWs and demanding adherence to the Geneva Convention. In 1996, Congress amended the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act to allow torture victims like American POWs to seek compensation from terrorist countries like Iraq. The American "human shield" victims from the Gulf War sought compensation for their injuries from terrorist countries, including Iraq. 17 Gulf War POWs and their families filed claims in the United States District Court for damages related to their torture and abuse by the Government of Iraq. The individuals seeking compensation for injuries from the Gulf War included retired military personnel from various branches such as USMC, USAF, U.S. Army, and Air National Guard. In 2003, a judge awarded damages to former POWs who were repeatedly tortured in Iraq, emphasizing the importance of deterring torture of POWs. A judge awarded damages to former POWs for being repeatedly tortured, emphasizing the need to deter such acts. However, the POWs and their families have not received payment due to a waiver granted for Iraq by the President under the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008. In December 2001, a US district court held Iraq liable for taking US citizens hostage after the invasion of Kuwait, awarding damages to 180 former hostages and their spouses. On March 20, 2003, before Operation Iraqi Freedom, the President directed payment for the judgments in Hill v. Republic of Iraq. On March 20, 2003, the President ordered payment for judgments in Hill v. Republic of Iraq from blocked Iraqi accounts. He also confiscated Iraq's remaining assets for deposit into the US Treasury for Iraq reconstruction, benefiting over 200 US citizens. The President ordered payment for judgments in Hill v. Republic of Iraq from blocked Iraqi accounts and confiscated Iraq's remaining assets for deposit into the US Treasury for Iraq reconstruction. Over 200 US citizens, including those in Vine v. Republic of Iraq, are awaiting compensation and unable to enforce any judgment due to a waiver granted for Iraq by the President. The plaintiffs in Vine v. Republic of Iraq have not been compensated and cannot enforce any judgment in US courts due to a waiver granted for Iraq by the President. Article 131 of the Third Geneva Convention prohibits the US from absolving Iraq of liability for torture of prisoners of war. The United States is obligated to protect its Armed Forces and citizens from torture and terrorism, holding state sponsors accountable. The US cannot absolve Iraq of liability for torture of prisoners of war. The Congress is committed to holding state sponsors of terrorism accountable. Unless certain claims against Iraq are settled within 30 days, the President's waiver authority will expire. The waiver authority granted to the President under the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008 will terminate after a 30-day period if certain claims against Iraq are not settled. This applies to specific cases in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008 grants the President waiver authority that will expire if certain claims against Iraq are not settled within 30 days. This applies to cases in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, where adequate settlement involves payment by the Government of Iraq or a US depository institution. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008 grants waiver authority to the President for settling claims against Iraq within 30 days in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. The Act specifies payments by a US depository institution to individuals with claims arising from hostage taking, with a maximum amount of $900,000. The Act allows for payments up to $900,000 for individuals with claims related to hostage taking, with additional compensation for each day held as a hostage and subjected to torture. The Act provides compensation of $2,500,000, plus $6,000 for each day as a hostage, to individuals who were subjected to torture while being held hostage and have not obtained a judgment before the enactment of the Act. Additionally, spouses or children of the victims are eligible for compensation. The Act provides compensation to individuals held as hostages, including spouses or children of the victims. One-third of the amount is allocated to spouses or children of the victims. Additionally, individuals who obtained a judgment for compensatory damages before the Act's enactment are eligible for compensation. The Act provides compensation to individuals held as hostages or their families. Those who obtained a judgment for compensatory damages before the Act's enactment may receive payment up to $1,000,000 or one-third of the excess amount if it exceeds $1,000,000. The Act provides compensation to hostages or their families. If a judgment exceeds $1,000,000, one-third of the excess amount may be paid. Definitions include "hostage" as an individual in hostage status or seized during an act of hostage taking. The Act provides compensation to hostages or their families who were detained in the commission of an act of hostage taking. Definitions include "hostage status" and "hostage taking" as specified in relevant laws. The term "person" includes the legal representative of a claimant's estate. "Torture" is defined in the Torture Victim Protection Act of 1991. "United States" refers to the several States, the District of Columbia, and any commonwealth, territory, or possession of the United States. The term "United States" includes the several States, the District of Columbia, and any commonwealth, territory, or possession of the United States. A "United States depository institution" refers to a depository institution organized under the laws of any State, the District of Columbia, or the United States. The Emergency Wartime Supplemental Appropriations Act of 2003 did not intend to remove jurisdiction over cases brought under section 1605(a)(7) of title 28, United States Code. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008 did not intend to remove jurisdiction over cases brought under section 1605(a)(7) of title 28, United States Code. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008 did not remove jurisdiction over cases under section 1605(a)(7) of title 28, United States Code. Section 1083(c) of the NDAA applies to cases specified in subsection (b)(2) from the date of enactment, regardless of any waiver for Iraq.
